ras_commander.RasUtils module

RasUtils - Utility functions for the ras-commander library

This module is part of the ras-commander library and uses a centralized logging configuration.

Logging Configuration: - The logging is set up in the logging_config.py file. - A @log_call decorator is available to automatically log function calls. - Log levels: DEBUG, INFO, WARNING, ERROR, CRITICAL - Logs are written to both console and a rotating file handler. - The default log file is ‘ras_commander.log’ in the ‘logs’ directory. - The default log level is INFO.

To use logging in this module: 1. Use the @log_call decorator for automatic function call logging. 2. For additional logging, use logger.[level]() calls (e.g., logger.info(), logger.debug()).

Example

@log_call def my_function():

logger.debug(“Additional debug information”) # Function logic here

class ras_commander.RasUtils.RasUtils[source]

Bases: object

A class containing utility functions for the ras-commander library. When integrating new functions that do not clearly fit into other classes, add them here.

static create_backup(file_path, backup_suffix='_backup', ras_object=None)[source]

Create a backup of the specified file.

Parameters: file_path (Path): Path to the file to be backed up backup_suffix (str): Suffix to append to the backup file name ras_object (RasPrj, optional): RAS object to use. If None, uses the default ras object.

Returns: Path: Path to the created backup file

Example: >>> backup_path = RasUtils.create_backup(Path(“project.prj”)) >>> print(f”Backup created at: {backup_path}”)

Parameters:

  • file_path (Path)

  • backup_suffix (str)

Return type:

Path

static restore_from_backup(backup_path, remove_backup=True, ras_object=None)[source]

Restore a file from its backup.

Parameters: backup_path (Path): Path to the backup file remove_backup (bool): Whether to remove the backup file after restoration ras_object (RasPrj, optional): RAS object to use. If None, uses the default ras object.

Returns: Path: Path to the restored file

Example: >>> restored_path = RasUtils.restore_from_backup(Path(“project_backup.prj”)) >>> print(f”File restored to: {restored_path}”)

Parameters:

  • backup_path (Path)

  • remove_backup (bool)

Return type:

Path

static get_plan_path(current_plan_number_or_path, ras_object=None)[source]

Get the path for a plan file with a given plan number or path.

Parameters: current_plan_number_or_path (Union[str, Path]): The plan number (1 to 99) or full path to the plan file ras_object (RasPrj, optional): RAS object to use. If None, uses the default ras object.

Returns: Path: Full path to the plan file

Example: >>> plan_path = RasUtils.get_plan_path(1) >>> print(f”Plan file path: {plan_path}”) >>> plan_path = RasUtils.get_plan_path(“path/to/plan.p01”) >>> print(f”Plan file path: {plan_path}”)

Parameters:

current_plan_number_or_path (str | Path)

Return type:

Path

static remove_with_retry(path, max_attempts=5, initial_delay=1.0, is_folder=True, ras_object=None)[source]

Attempts to remove a file or folder with retry logic and exponential backoff.

Parameters: path (Path): Path to the file or folder to be removed. max_attempts (int): Maximum number of removal attempts. initial_delay (float): Initial delay between attempts in seconds. is_folder (bool): If True, the path is treated as a folder; if False, it’s treated as a file. ras_object (RasPrj, optional): RAS object to use. If None, uses the default ras object.

Returns: bool: True if the file or folder was successfully removed, False otherwise.

Example: >>> success = RasUtils.remove_with_retry(Path(“temp_folder”), is_folder=True) >>> print(f”Removal successful: {success}”)

Parameters:

  • path (Path)

  • max_attempts (int)

  • initial_delay (float)

  • is_folder (bool)

Return type:

bool

static update_plan_file(plan_number_or_path, file_type, entry_number, ras_object=None)[source]

Update a plan file with a new file reference.

Parameters: plan_number_or_path (Union[str, Path]): The plan number (1 to 99) or full path to the plan file file_type (str): Type of file to update (‘Geom’, ‘Flow’, or ‘Unsteady’) entry_number (int): Number (from 1 to 99) to set ras_object (RasPrj, optional): RAS object to use. If None, uses the default ras object.

Raises: ValueError: If an invalid file_type is provided FileNotFoundError: If the plan file doesn’t exist

Example: >>> RasUtils.update_plan_file(1, “Geom”, 2) >>> RasUtils.update_plan_file(“path/to/plan.p01”, “Geom”, 2)

Parameters:

  • plan_number_or_path (str | Path)

  • file_type (str)

  • entry_number (int)

Return type:

None

static convert_to_dataframe(data_source, **kwargs)[source]

Converts input to a pandas DataFrame. Supports existing DataFrames or file paths (CSV, Excel, TSV, Parquet).

Parameters:

  • data_source (Union[pd.DataFrame, Path]) – The input to convert to a DataFrame. Can be a file path or an existing DataFrame.

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments to pass to pandas read functions.

Returns:

The resulting DataFrame.

Return type:

pd.DataFrame

Raises:

NotImplementedError – If the file type is unsupported or input type is invalid.

Example

>>> df = RasUtils.convert_to_dataframe(Path("data.csv"))
>>> print(type(df))
<class 'pandas.core.frame.DataFrame'>
static save_to_excel(dataframe, excel_path, **kwargs)[source]

Saves a pandas DataFrame to an Excel file with retry functionality.

Parameters:

  • dataframe (pd.DataFrame) – The DataFrame to save.

  • excel_path (Path) – The path to the Excel file where the DataFrame will be saved.

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments passed to DataFrame.to_excel().

Raises:

IOError – If the file cannot be saved after multiple attempts.

Return type:

None

Example

>>> df = pd.DataFrame({'A': [1, 2, 3], 'B': [4, 5, 6]})
>>> RasUtils.save_to_excel(df, Path('output.xlsx'))
static calculate_rmse(observed_values, predicted_values, normalized=True)[source]

Calculate the Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) between observed and predicted values.

Parameters:

  • observed_values (np.ndarray) – Actual observations time series.

  • predicted_values (np.ndarray) – Estimated/predicted time series.

  • normalized (bool, optional) – Whether to normalize RMSE to a percentage of observed_values. Defaults to True.

Returns:

The calculated RMSE value.

Return type:

float

Example

>>> observed = np.array([1, 2, 3])
>>> predicted = np.array([1.1, 2.2, 2.9])
>>> RasUtils.calculate_rmse(observed, predicted)
0.06396394
static calculate_percent_bias(observed_values, predicted_values, as_percentage=False)[source]

Calculate the Percent Bias between observed and predicted values.

Parameters:

  • observed_values (np.ndarray) – Actual observations time series.

  • predicted_values (np.ndarray) – Estimated/predicted time series.

  • as_percentage (bool, optional) – If True, return bias as a percentage. Defaults to False.

Returns:

The calculated Percent Bias.

Return type:

float

Example

>>> observed = np.array([1, 2, 3])
>>> predicted = np.array([1.1, 2.2, 2.9])
>>> RasUtils.calculate_percent_bias(observed, predicted, as_percentage=True)
3.33333333
static calculate_error_metrics(observed_values, predicted_values)[source]

Compute a trio of error metrics: correlation, RMSE, and Percent Bias.

Parameters:

  • observed_values (np.ndarray) – Actual observations time series.

  • predicted_values (np.ndarray) – Estimated/predicted time series.

Returns:

A dictionary containing correlation (‘cor’), RMSE (‘rmse’), and Percent Bias (‘pb’).

Return type:

Dict[str, float]

Example

>>> observed = np.array([1, 2, 3])
>>> predicted = np.array([1.1, 2.2, 2.9])
>>> RasUtils.calculate_error_metrics(observed, predicted)
{'cor': 0.9993, 'rmse': 0.06396, 'pb': 0.03333}
